item.title: 'A total miscue' - England finally get breakthrough as Head departs
item.description: After being dropped on three, England remove Travis Head for 33 for their first Australian wicket of the second Test, with Gus Atkinson taking the catch off the bowling of Brydon Carse, with the home side 77-1 in their first innings in Brisbane.

item.title: UK to deport 60 delivery riders after illegal work crackdown
item.description: The Home Office says the group are among 171 riders arrested over seven days in November in a national "enforcement blitz".

item.title: We'll end children living in B&Bs, government says in child poverty pledge
item.description: The strategy also includes making childcare more accessible for families on Universal Credit.

item.title: Labuschagne takes brilliant diving catch as England all out for 334
item.description: Marnus Labuschagne dives at full stretch to take a brilliant catch in the deep from Jofra Archer, as England are bowled out for 334 runs on day two of the second Ashes Test in Brisbane.

item.title: Teen influencers on Australia's world-first social media ban
item.description: Australia is banning social media for everyone under 16 from December 10. The BBC spoke to two teenage content creators about how this might change their lives.

item.title: Man who killed ex-Japan PM Shinzo Abe apologises to his family
item.description: Tetsuya Yamagami said during his trial that he felt '"deeply sorry" towards Abe's widow Akie.

item.title: Faroe Islands scraps one of Europe's strictest abortion laws
item.description: Politicians in the self-governing Danish territory have voted to overturn legislation which banned abortion in most cases.

item.title: Shooter of Ex-Japan PM Shinzo Abe makes first apology
item.description: Tetsuya Yamagami said during his trial that he felt '"deeply sorry" towards Abe's widow Akie.

item.title: US Supreme Court allows Texas to use redrawn voting maps in midterms
item.description: The electoral map could boost the Republican effort to shore up their majority in the coming 2026 midterm elections.

item.title: 'Deep indignation' after Ukraine diver switches to Russia
item.description: The Ukrainian Diving Federation wants diver Sofiia Lyskun to be stripped of all awards after the European champion switched her international allegiance to Russia.

item.title: Details of plan to keep pubs open longer for World Cup revealed
item.description: Licensing hours could be extended to 01:00 if a home nation reaches the final stages next summer.

item.title: Admiral testified Hegseth did not give 'kill them all' order, US lawmakers say
item.description: The admiral who gave the order for a second strike on an alleged drug boat briefed lawmakers about the incident, as the military confirmed another attack.

item.title: Frustration and anger - why 'huge question marks' hang over Man Utd
item.description: Ruben Amorim declares himself angry and frustrated as his Manchester United side again lose a lead - with consistency continuing to be an issue.

item.title: We would sell books by AI, says Waterstones boss
item.description: James Daunt says booksellers instinctively have "disdain" for AI but it could be sold if clearly labelled.

item.title: What legal experts say about second US strike on Venezuela boat
item.description: Several legal experts have told BBC Verify that there was no legal basis for the second strike on an alleged Venezuelan drug boat by the US military.

item.title: Weekly quiz: Where did shopkeepers find a drunk raccoon?
item.description: How much attention did you pay to what happened in the world over the past seven days?

item.title: The Papers: Russian assets 'deal' plan and 'Joe the GOAT'
item.description: A mixed range of stories feature on Friday's front page - but many picture England cricketer Joe Root after his heroics in the Ashes.

item.title: Why I'm terrified of motorways even though I've been driving for 20 years
item.description: A woman shares her experience of driving anxiety and a driving coach gives tips to combat this fear.

item.title: Top UK scientist says research visa restrictions endanger economy
item.description: Prof Sir Paul Nurse says the UK is "shooting itself in the foot" with its visa system for researchers.

item.title: Anthony Zurcher: Boat strike briefings help Hegseth - but shipwreck video release may hurt
item.description: Republicans and Democrats agreed he didn't order killing everyone on an alleged drug boat. That's where the consensus ended.

item.title: Turkey breeder supplying luxury stores investigated over welfare
item.description: Farm workers are suspended over animal welfare and biosecurity concerns at a turkey breeding site.

item.title: My husband would still be alive if he'd got Post Office compensation
item.description: The widow and daughter of Jonathan Armstrong tell the BBC about the toll the Horizon scandal took on his health.

item.title: How a 'fertility gap' is fuelling the rise of one-child families
item.description: The proportion of UK families with one child has grown since the turn of the century - with knock-on effects for society
